title: Rubygems does not comply with XDG basedir spec
body:
I would like to suggest a feature.

My current problem is rubygems does not respect the [XDG specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/basedir-spec-latest.html) for user configuration data.

The XDG basedir spec specifies where user-specific configuration data should go and allows users control of where tools read/write their configuration data.

To be compliant, rubygems ought to be using `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/gem/config` as its configuration file (where `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` defaults to `$HOME/.config/`).

Since there is an existing directory where data can be read to/from, it is clearly important that the existing file path (`~/.gemrc`) be respected if it exists and to migrate to the new path.

Recommendation:

Use `~/.gemrc` if and only if it already exists.
Otherwise use `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/gem/config` (or perhaps `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/rubygems/config` ?).

Per the spec, `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME` defaults to `$HOME/.config` if it is not set.

There should be a separate discussion for `~/.gem/credentials`, which should either go under `XDG_CONFIG_HOME/gem`, `$XDG_DATA_HOME/gem` or `$XDG_CACHE_HOME/gem` (depending on how the credentials file is viewed). For now, I'd like to keep this issue focused solely on the location of gemrc.

This issue is related to:

  - [ ] Network problems
  - [ ] Installing a library
  - [ ] Publishing a library
  - [x] The command line `gem`
  - [ ] Other

Here are my current environment details:

```
$ gem env version
2.2.2
```

title: Update `update_bundled_ca_certificates` utility script for directory nesting
body:
- Also updates the ssl certs with the minimum certs needed and nests them in directories named for the hosts they can authenticate against. The arrangement of the certs changed/occurred because the ssl certs in Rubygems were modeled after the ssl cert arrangement in Bundler. However, this arrangement was produced through manual testing and configured/arranged in bundler/bundler#4380 instead of programmatically. I'm unsure how I would go about writing or updating the `update_bundled_ca_certificates` script in a way that could reproduce this current manual arrangement. Hence, this PR includes a commit for rearranging of the ssl certs based off the programmatic utility script (instead of a manual process).
- Related to discussion at #1555

title: Specs sorting in Gem::Specification._resort!() should be stable
body:
I'm having a problem or would like to suggest a feature.
I'm having a problem

My current problem is _________
I have a script that has to run with JRuby, it depends on several gems, some with JRuby versions, some don't and some have both, I've setup my GEM_PATH so that JRuby gem path is before regular gem path, such as: [path-to-JRuby-gems-lib]:[path-to-non-JRuby-gems-lib]. My expectation is when a gem has JRuby version, RubyGems will load the JRuby version. I found that sometimes RubyGems behaves as I expected, sometimes it doesn't. After some digging up I found this method in [specification.rb](https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/blob/0e3c58e7fa3a8f1f69ca3e74067af6fb3cb2eb11/lib/rubygems/specification.rb#L859), it uses Array.sort!() to sort specs by name and version, it is not stable sort, which means when a gem is installed in both the JRuby gems path and the regular gems path, it is non-deterministic about which version will be loaded after you add or remove new gems to your library.

This issue is related to:

  - [ ] Network problems
  - [ ] Installing a library
  - [ ] Publishing a library
  - [ ] The command line `gem`
  - [x] Other

Here are my current envrionment details:

My environment doesn't matter, I've linked to the latest commit of [specification.rb](https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/blob/0e3c58e7fa3a8f1f69ca3e74067af6fb3cb2eb11/lib/rubygems/specification.rb#L859) and it's still an unstable sort.

```
  def cache_update_path uri, path = nil, update = true
    mtime = path && File.stat(path).mtime rescue nil

    data = fetch_path(uri, mtime)

    if data == nil # indicates the server returned 304 Not Modified
      return Gem.read_binary(path)
    end

    if update and path
      open(path, 'wb') do |io|
        begin
          io.flock(File::LOCK_EX)
        rescue Errno::ENOTSUP
        end
        io.write data
      end
    end

    data
  end
```

title: Running update_rubygems may happen to fail on Windows
body:
After installing/updating the rubygems-update gem, update_rubygems script execution may happen to fail on Windows with the following error:

Cannot find RubyGems Update Path!

In my opinion this happens in the following scenario:

- Install Ruby 2.2.4 on Windows, 32 or 64 bit version does not matter
- Install the rubygems-update gem, say version 2.5.2

	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/security/signer.rb:54:in `map'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/security/signer.rb:54:in `initialize'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/package.rb:481:in `new'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/package.rb:481:in `setup_signer'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/package.rb:250:in `build'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/package.rb:115:in `build'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/commands/build_command.rb:53:in `execute'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/command.rb:310:in `invoke_with_build_args'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/command_manager.rb:169:in `process_args'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/command_manager.rb:139:in `run'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/lib/ruby/site_ruby/2.2.0/rubygems/gem_runner.rb:55:in `run'
	/Users/smoss/.rbenv/versions/2.2.3/bin/gem:21:in `<main>'
```

I tracked this down to [line 57 of security/signer.rb](https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/blob/master/lib/rubygems/security/signer.rb#L57) `cert = File.read cert if File.exist? cert`

This actually turned out to be my error in providing the incorrect certificate filename for the cert_chain in my gemspec file. However, if the file doesn't exist, the code simply returns the original filename as a String, which [line 59](https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/blob/master/lib/rubygems/security/signer.rb#L59) `OpenSSL::X509::Certificate.new cert` then attempts to continue as if it were the certificate file content.

There should probably be a more explicit check and error message here, e.g. something like:

```
begin
  cert = File.read cert
rescue => e
  puts "#{e.message}"
end
```

title: Requiring an .so file via Ruby will not work with RubyGems
body:
If I require a .so file via Ruby's require, it works.  But if I do the same thing via RubyGems, it won't work.  Here is an example:

```
# Put nokogiri's lib dir on the load path so that RubyGems isn't used, then require the .so file
[aaron@TC ~]$ ruby -I $(dirname `gem which nokogiri`) -e'l = $LOADED_FEATURES.dup; require "nokogiri/nokogiri.so"; p $LOADED_FEATURES - l'
["/Users/aaron/.rbenv/versions/ruby-trunk/lib/ruby/gems/2.4.0/gems/nokogiri-1.6.8.rc3-x86_64-darwin-15/lib/nokogiri/nokogiri.bundle"]
```

Ruby automatically deals with the .so -> .bundle conversion (so that the require is cross platform).

If I remove Nokogiri from the load path, then RubyGems will not behave the same way Ruby does:

I expect the `require` call to work without being changed, but what actually happens is that RubyGems raises an exception.

title: We still need an alternative to yank -- how about 'hide'?
body:
Opening this because I think #858 was closed without understanding the point of why that issue was opened.

The changes that were made to permadelete (http://blog.rubygems.org/2015/04/13/permadelete-on-yank.html) solved issues around the usability for the use case when you really should yank a gem -- where you've pushed sensitive credentials in the gem, or it has some kind of heartbleed-level epic security hole, and you really need to delete it in order to mitigate the impact.

The problem comes when gems are yanked when they're just buggy.  I ran into this before when I yanked ohai 7.6.0 awhile after it was released and broke every Gemfile.lock which had pinned ohai to that version.   We also just got bit today by github_changelog_generator yanking quite a few versions that were released in the past 2 days (1.10.2,1.10.3,1.10.5,1.11.0).

As a minimum viable proposal what I'd like to suggest is a way to 'hide' a gem.  When a gem is 'hidden' it should appear marked as 'hidden' instead of 'yanked' in the rubygems API.   As a result of being hidden the depsolver will not use it to find solutions to constraints (failing the solve if there's no alternative).  But the gem can be installed with 'gem install -v' and Gemfile.locks with hidden gems in them will still be able to pull the gem down and will not break by the action of the gem being 'hidden'.

This gets more at the use case that is often, incorrectly, what users are trying to accomplish when using 'gem yank':

- users which are happily using the 'broken' gem can still use it (presumably they're not affected by the bug)
- new users never get the 'broken' gem

I don't really think its necessary to publish the 'reason' for why the gem was hidden.  Generally interested users will be able to find the reason on the issue tracker for the project. I think that all that is necessary is just implementing the 'hide' mechanism.

title: How do I securely release gems?

title: Code of Conduct link to project maintainers
Fix incorrect dir globs when have_extensions? is true
body:
Before this change `lib_dirs_glob` would return this for the glob if `have_extensions?` was true:

```
"/private/var/folders/fy/rml6_y9x3b392jpmpy160g7r0000gn/T/test_rubygems_64679/gemhome/gems/a-2/{/private/var/folders/fy/rml6_y9x3b392jpmpy160g7r0000gn/T/test_rubygems_64679/gemhome/extensions/x86-darwin-8/2.3.0-static/a-2,lib}"
```

As you can see the extensions directory ends up inside the curly braces so the glob will never actually find anything in the extensions directory.

This commit changes the glob to look like this:
```
{/private/var/folders/fy/rml6_y9x3b392jpmpy160g7r0000gn/T/test_rubygems_64904/gemhome/extensions/x86-darwin-8/2.3.0-static/a-2,lib}"
```

It looks like when extensions are built the shared object is copied to the lib dir as well as the extensions dir. When we're searching for a shared object which one do we want? The lib dir or the extension dir? If we want the extensions dir then we need this patch to fix. If we want the lib dir then there's no point in adding the extensions dir to the lib dir glob.

cc/ @drbrain

title: Add Gem::Specification#required_engine_version
body:
This is a followup to issue #1263.

This PR adds the Gem::Specification#required_engine_version member to deal with the limitations of the required_ruby_version, which was originally put in place when there was only one implementation. With multiple Ruby implementations now in the wild, it's necessary to not only specify a Ruby version, but an engine version as well in some cases.

I've also added a Gem.ruby_engine_version singleton method. There's already a Gem.ruby_engine singleton, so it makes sense to add it, and I use it internally in the installer code.
